item.title: backcasting
item.description: It consists in fitting a model to reproduce reference (statistical) data. The idea is to find the mechanism which explains the input/output transformation.

item.title: complexity
item.description: In the ethymological sense, cum (with) et plexus (weave): what is woven together. It cannot be decomposed without being denatured.

item.title: complexity sciences
item.description: Represented by the Santa Fe Institute (SFI) or the ISC-PIF. The Nobel Price winner in 1965, Gell-Mann, co-founded the SFI. References are Ilya Prigogine, David Ruelle, Mandelbrot, Lorentz, Poincaré, Hadamard, Stephen Wolfram.

item.title: deductive system
item.description: A deductive system is composed of axioms and rules of inference.

item.title: formal language
item.description: A formal language consists of: an alphabet a syntax for the alphabet There must be a decision procedure (see decidability) for membership in well-formed sentences.

item.title: formal system
item.description: A formal system is a combination of a formal language and a deductive system that imposes a semantic. Sources Wikipedia Standford Encyclopedia

item.title: Groupe des Dix
item.description: The members were: Edgar Morin Henri Atlan Joël de Rosay Jean-Pierre Dupuy Jacques Attali André Leroi-Gourhan Michel Rocard Michel Serres

item.title: ISC-PIF
item.description: Institute of complexity science in Paris founded in 2005.

item.title: predicate
item.description: A predicate is a fonctionalized proposition that refers to a property of input objects from a specific domain. The arity is the number of inputs.

item.title: Santa Fe Institute (SFI)
item.description: Founded in 1984 in Santa Fe, it is an instute for physical complex systems.

item.title: semantic
item.description: It refers to the meaning, the interpretation, or the truth-value (in logic) of a sentence.

item.title: syntax
item.description: In linguistics, it relates how words are assembled to form larger units.

item.title: molecular chaperon
item.description: They aid proteins to fold by restricting conformations. They are driving forces, such as the solvent.

item.title: prion
item.description: The word comes from “proteinaceous infectious particle”. Prions are misfolded proteins that have the ability to transmit their misfolded shape onto normal variants of the same protein.

item.title: deterministic system
item.description: A system is deterministic when it has a conceivable determination in explicit mathematics. It does not require the maths to be solvable in practice.

item.title: entropy
item.description: For a given phase space, Hamiltonian and energy, entropy quantifies the number of micro-states available. Details In the Gibbs (canonical) ensemble (NVT), the partition function reads $$ Z = \sum_i e^{-\beta E_i} $$an with the probability of the micro-state $i$ being $p_i=e^{-\beta E_i} / Z$, we have $$ S_G=-k_B \sum_i p_i \log(p_i) $$

item.title: abacus
item.description: An abacus is a “higher-level” (more flexible) Turing machine for computation. Every abacus-computable function is Turing computable. All recursive functions are abacus-computable.

item.title: arithmetic function
item.description: A function whose domain is $\mathbb{N}$.

item.title: enumerable set
item.description: A set is enumerable if and only if it is the range of some arithmetic function. (The range is the set of the function’s values.

item.title: recursive function
item.description: It refers to functions that can be built with the zero, the successor and the identity function by use of composition, minimization and primitive recursion: $$h(x,0)=f(x), \ h(x,y’)=g(x,y,h(x,y))$$
